items.title: How investigators pieced together the plot to target Bondi
items.description: Security camera footage captured the Bondi Beach gunmen carrying what appears to be firearms out of a south-west Sydney property on the morning of the terror attack, court documents reveal.

items.title: Fast cars and big debts: The unravelling of Steve Cubis
items.description: Steven Cubis hides behind a charming facade, but his former lover and friends say the career con man ruined them financially and emotionally long before he was caught up in allegations of a multi-million-dollar fraud.

items.title: Gas lobby turns to liquid under pressure
items.description: The gas export industry has cost the nation dearly. East coast prices trebled soon after exports began.

items.title: 'Extremely cunning': Taipei metro attacker planned assault for over a year
items.description: Police in Taiwan say Chang Wen purchased grenades, gas canisters and respirators in the year leading up to Friday's attack.

items.title: Teens flock to alternative apps after social media ban
items.description: The Commonwealth's long-awaited social media ban for under-16s came into effect this month. But some experts note a rise in alternatives to popular platforms as teens find ways to stay active on social media.

items.title: World's largest warship looms near Venezuela as US warns of land attacks
items.description: The Pentagon has moved the USS Gerald R Ford, the world's largest aircraft carrier, to the Caribbean. Now President Donald Trump is repeating threats of imminent strikes against Venezuelan territory.

items.title: Car bomb kills Russian army general in Moscow, officials say
items.description: The Kremlin is probing who is behind the killing, which has similarities to previous attacks by Ukrainian special services.

items.title: British singer-songwriter Chris Rea dies aged 74
items.description: The man best known for his festive hit Driving Home for Christmas died surrounded by his family.

items.title: City Beach fined $14m over 'pervasive' button battery safety failures
items.description: The Federal Court orders the fashion retailer to pay $14 million in fines after it was taken to court by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.

items.title: A chaotic 'up-crash' for markets riding a turbulent 2025
items.description: AI. Market records. Tariffs. Penguins. TACO. It's been a big year of economic shocks and surges as the international framework of global trade was shredded. Here's how key players saw the year that was.

items.title: Swiss court to hear islanders' climate change case against cement giant
items.description: Residents of the tiny Indonesian island of Pari, which risks being swallowed by rising seas, win the right to have their have their climate change case against cement giant Holcim heard in a Swiss court.

items.title: Measles cases triple in Australia as global outbreaks continue
items.description: The number of measles cases nationwide is now approaching triple the number of cases reported in 2024 as outbreaks continue around the world.

items.title: FRV sues firefighters union over $1.6m in taxpayer-funded 'service fees'
items.description: Taxpayers have funded $1.6 million in payments to the firefighters union via Fire Rescue Victoria, court documents allege, under an income protection scheme the state's fire chief has said should outrage all Victorians.

items.title: Police investigate two fatal stabbings in Melbourne
items.description: A man died after he was stabbed during an altercation in Clyde, in Melbourne's south-east. Just hours later another man was fatally stabbed in Fitzroy.

items.title: Quiz: Can you pick the real Christmas movies from these unhinged plots?
items.description: Once December rolls around, there's nothing the minor movie studios love more than getting their most unhinged Christmas tropes out of cold storage.

items.title: Uruguay was the first country to legalise marijuana — with mixed results
items.description: Twelve years ago today, Uruguay became the first country to legalise recreational marijuana use. The experiment is still unfolding.

items.title: Vinyl's dirty secret: Why your records hurt the planet
items.description: Artists like Stella Donnelly are searching for ways to cut waste and make production of their albums environmentally friendly.

items.title: Thailand-Cambodia ceasefire deal 'rushed' for Donald Trump
items.description: Bangkok says the two countries will return to the negotiating table this week amid claims the initial peace deal was rushed for Donald Trump.

items.title: Japan prepares to restart world's biggest nuclear plant, 15 years after Fukushima
items.description: Japan has taken the final step to allow the world's largest nuclear power plant to resume operations with a regional vote in Niigata prefecture.

items.title: New high-tech cameras making a difference to NSW fire fighting
items.description: New cameras using AI have been installed in southern New South Wales forests and are spotting fires before they have a chance to spread.

items.title: National DV register 'could have helped' woman killed by ex-partner, daughter says
items.description: Advocates are pushing for a national framework for addressing domestic violence after an ABC investigation highlighted gaps in the justice system and a lack of information sharing between states.

items.title: Queensland man arrested following dozens of antisemitic graffiti offences
items.description: A Coolum Beach man is charged with 25 counts of wilful damage following a spate of antisemitic graffiti incidents.

items.title: Man accused of planning racial hatred event at Cronulla refused bail
items.description: A 20-year-old who allegedly tried to organise a racial hatred event at Cronulla on the same day as the Bondi Beach terrorist attack is refused bail.

items.title: Thousands of birds are dying on a remote island, with no end in sight
items.description: The Isle of May is the epicentre of a deadly outbreak of the H5N1 bird flu strain which has spread throughout the globe. Scientists are warning Australia could be next.

items.title: Liberal-linked Tasmanian public relations firm Font PR closes its doors
items.description: It has helped keep the Liberals in power in Tasmania and lobbied on behalf of Airbnb, the salmon industry and the Catholic Church — but the PR firm, described as having "fingers in a lot of pies", is closing down.
